tn.text: The part of the story from the previous chapter continues. Jesus is standing before Pilate as he is being accused by the Jews.

tn.ref: Then Pilate took Jesus and whipped him
tn.text: Pilate himself did not whip Jesus. Here "Pilate" is a synecdoche for the soldiers that Pilate ordered to whip Jesus. AT: "Then Pilate ordered his soldiers to whip Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The greeting "Hail" with a raised hand was only used to greet Caesar. As the soldiers use the crown of thorns and the purple robe to mock Jesus, it is ironic that they do not recognize that he is indeed a king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: I find no guilt in him
tn.text: Pilate states this twice to say he does not believe Jesus is not guilty of any crime. He does not want to punish him. AT: "I see no reason to punish him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The crown and the purple robe are things only kings wear. The soldiers dressed Jesus in this manner to mock him. See [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:19:01|19:2]].
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish leaders answered Pilate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: he has to die because he claimed to be the Son of God
tn.text: Jesus was condemned to death by crucifixion because he claimed he was "the Son of God."
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: Are you not speaking to me?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question. Here Pilate expresses his surprise that Jesus does not take the opportunity to defend himself. AT: "I cannot believe you are refusing to speak to me" or "Answer me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Do you not know that I have power to release you, and power to crucify you?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to add emphasis. AT: "You should know that I am able to release you or to order my soldiers to crucify you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "power" is a metonym that refers to the ability to do something or to cause something to happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You do not have any power over me except for what has been given to you from above
tn.text: You can translate this double negative in a positive and active form. AT: "You are able to act against me only because God has made you able" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a respectful way of referring to God.
This phrase here means to hand over to an enemy.
Here "this answer" refers to Jesus' answer. AT: "When Pilate heard Jesus' answer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The form of "tried" in the original indicates that Pilate tried "hard" or "repeatedly" to release Jesus. AT: "he tried hard to release Jesus" or "he tried again and again to release Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here "Jews" is a synecdoche that refers to the Jewish leaders that opposed Jesus. In the original, the form of "cried out" indicates that they cried out or shouted repeatedly. AT: "but the Jewish leaders kept shouting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: you are not a friend of Caesar
tn.text: "you are opposing Caesar" or "you are opposing the emperor"
"claims that he is a king"
Here "he" refers to Pilate and is a synecdoche for "Pilate ordered the soldiers." AT: "he ordered the soldiers to bring Jesus out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Important people like Pilate sat down when they performed an official duty, while people who were not so important stood up.
This is the special chair that an important person like Pilate sat in when he was making an official judgment. If your language has a special way to describe this action, you can use it here.

This is a special stone platform where only the important people were allowed to go. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "in a place the people called The Pavement," (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the language that the people of Israel spoke.
Some time has passed and it is now the sixth hour, as Pilate orders his soldiers to crucify Jesus.
This word marks a break in the storyline so that John can provide information about the upcoming Passover and the time of day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"about noontime"
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche that refers to the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "Pilate said to the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "I" is a synecdoche that refers to Pilate's soldiers who will actually perform the crucifixion. AT: "Do you really want me to tell my soldiers to nail your king to a cross?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Then Pilate gave Jesus over to them to be crucified
tn.text: Here Pilate gives the order for his soldiers to crucify Jesus. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "So Pilate ordered his soldiers to crucify Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: to the place called "The Place of a Skull,"
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "to the place that the people called 'The Place of a Skull,'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Hebrew is the language of the people of Israel. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "which in Hebrew they call 'Golgotha.'"
This is an ellipsis. You can translate this, adding the implied words. AT: "they also nailed two other criminals to their crosses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Pilate also wrote a sign and put it on the cross
tn.text: Here "Pilate" is a synecdoche for the person who wrote on the sign. Here "on the cross" refers to Jesus' cross. AT: "Pilate also commanded someone to write on a sign and to attach it to Jesus' cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: There it was written: JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "So that person wrote the words: Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the place where Jesus was crucified
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "the place where the soldiers crucified Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The sign was written in Hebrew, in Latin, and in Greek
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "The one who prepared the sign wrote the words in 3 languages: Hebrew, Latin, and Greek" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This was the language of the Roman government.

tn.ref: Then the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate
tn.text: The chief priests had to go back to Pilate's headquarters to protest to him about the words on the sign. AT: "The chief priests went back to Pilate and said" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: What I have written I have written
tn.text: Pilate implies that he will not change the words on the sign. AT: "I have written what I wanted to write, and I will not change it!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
At the end of verse 24 there is a break from the main storyline as the John tells us how this event fulfills Scriture. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"and they also took his tunic." The soldiers kept the tunic separate and did not divide it. AT: "and they kept his tunic separate" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: let us cast lots for it to decide whose it will be
tn.text: The soldiers will gamble and the winner will receive the shirt. AT: "let us gamble for the tunic and the winner will get to keep it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that the scripture would be fulfilled which said
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "This fulfilled the scripture that said" or "This happened to make the scripture come true which said"
This was how the soldiers divided Jesus' clothing among themselves. AT: "they gambled"
This is John, the writer of this Gospel.

Here the word "son" is a metaphor. Jesus wants his disciple, John, to be like a son to his mother. AT: "Woman, here is the man who will act like a son to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "mother" is a metaphor. Jesus wants his mother to be like a mother to his disciple, John. AT: "Think of this woman as if she were your own mother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"From that very moment" (UDB)

tn.ref: knowing that everything was now completed
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "he knew that he had done everything that God had sent him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: A container full of sour wine was placed there
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "Someone had placed there a full container of sour wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"bitter wine"
Here "they" refers to the Roman guards.
a small object that can soak up and hold much liquid
"on a branch of a plant called hyssop"

tn.ref: He bowed his head and gave up his spirit
tn.text: John implies here that Jesus gave his spirit back to God. AT: "He bowed his head and gave God his spirit" or "He bowed his head and died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the time before the Passover when people prepared food for the Passover.

tn.ref: to break their legs and to remove them
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "to break the legs of the executed men and take their bodies down from the crosses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: who had been crucified with Jesus
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "whom they had crucified near Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This sentence gives background information to the story. John is telling readers that he was there and that we can trust what he has written. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: has testified, and his testimony is true
tn.text: To "testify" means to tell about something that one has seen. AT: "has told the truth about what he has seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: so that you would also believe
tn.text: Here "believe" means to put one's trust in Jesus. AT: "so that you will also put your trust in Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
In these verses there is a break from the main storyline as John tells us about how these events have made Scripture come true. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
You can translate this in an active form. AT: "to fulfill the words that someone wrote in the scripture" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Not one of his bones will be broken
tn.text: This is a quotation from Psalm 34. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "No one will break any of his bones" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They will look at him whom they pierced
tn.text: This is a quotation from Zechariah 12.
Arimathea was a small town. AT: "Joseph from the town of Arimathea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "for fear of the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: if he could take away the body of Jesus
tn.text: John implies that Joseph of Arimathea wants to bury the body of Jesus. AT: "for permission to take the body of Jesus down from the cross for burial" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Nicodemus was one of the Pharisees who believed in Jesus. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:03:01|3:1]].
These are spices that people use to prepare a body for burial.
"100" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A "litra" is a measurement of weight equal to 31 grams. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:12:01|12:3]].

tn.ref: Now in the place where he was crucified there was a garden ... had yet been buried
tn.text: Here John marks a break in the storyline in order to provide background information about the location of the tomb where they would bury Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Now in the place where he was crucified there was a garden
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "Now in the place where they crucified Jesus there was a garden" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in which no person had yet been buried
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "in which people had buried no one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Because it was the day of preparation for the Jews
tn.text: According to Jewish law, no one could work after sundown on Friday. It was the beginning of the Sabbath and Passover. AT: "The Passover was about to begin that evening" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
